intro: Jarilla chocola, commonly known as chocolate weed, is a low-growing plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that bloom in clusters, often resembling a cluster of tiny candles. Its name derives from the chocolate-brown color of its stems and leaves, which can be used in traditional herbal remedies. Jarilla chocola is drought-tolerant and thrives in well-drained soils, making it a hardy plant suited for xeriscaping.
